subject: RE: [junit] Guidelines/Best Practices for writing JUnit Test cases
msgSnippet: I guess Joe Rainsberger s reply has a value point.  Using a search engine certainly brings up a lot but not necessarily the most accurate information.  It is
messageBody:
I guess Joe Rainsberger's reply has a value point. Using a search
engine certainly brings up a lot but not necessarily the most accurate
information. It is tempting to answer a question with a reference to a
search engine but no one can guarantee what shows up in a day, a week,
or any time.



I don't have a list of online references for best practices available.
Maybe a look at the JUnit FAQ might help to find more information?
http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm#tests.



There is also a very good book available, and since the author does not
mention it, I take the freedom to do it: JUnit Recipes
http://www.manning.com/rainsberger/.





Andreas



________________________________

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
J. B. Rainsberger
Sent: Tuesday, July 04, 2006 6:25 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Guidelines/Best Practices for writing JUnit Test
cases



Joe Schmetzer wrote:

> On Tue, 4 July, 2006 9:00 am, Harshal Shah wrote:
> > Are there some guidelines/Best practices for writing good JUnit Test
> > cases?
> >
> > Any pointers would be helpful
>
> The following search returned some pretty good hits:
>
> http://www.google.com/search?q=junit+best+practices
<http://www.google.com/search?q=junit+best+practices>
> <http://www.google.com/search?q=junit+best+practices
<http://www.google.com/search?q=junit+best+practices> >
>
> Good luck!

I read the first hit article. It had so many errors in it, I got sick.
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger :: http://www.jbrains.info
<http://www.jbrains.info>
Your guide to software craftsmanship
JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
2005 Gordon Pask Award for contribution Agile Software Practice
